thread.title: Is The Trans-Pacific Partnership a Goldmine For These Companies? - TheStreet
thread.title_full: Is The Trans-Pacific Partnership a Goldmine For These Companies? - TheStreet

author: yahoo
title: Is The Trans-Pacific Partnership a Goldmine For These Companies? - TheStreet
text:
Reddit Email Print Reprint NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- Negotiators announced last week that most of the final details of the Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP) have been worked out, leaving it now to the governments of the 12 participating countries -- including the United States -- to ratify the deal.
The TPP can be a boon for businesses around the Pacific Rim, especially for American companies. It covers trade among countries that account for roughly 40% of the global economy and more than $1 trillion in goods and services.

Much of Asia is growing at a healthy rate of between 4% and 8%, as both population and purchasing power are expanding quickly. Thanks to the TPP, many companies will find they can reach nearly 500 million new Asian customers much more cheaply.
For instance, while Ford ( F - Get Report ) and General Motors ( GM - Get Report ) aren't pleased that the TPP will phase out tariffs on cars and parts from countries participating in the deal, it also means that the duo of American auto makers will also eventually have freer access to those markets as well. In 2012, the Big Three U.S. automakers only sold 13,637 cars in the Japanese market. That's less than Japanese companies sold in a single day here in the U.S., despite the fact that Japan is the third largest automobile market in the world.

So while Asia Pacific accounted for just less than 7.5% of Ford's sales last year and even less for General Motors, American automakers will find a move level playing field in the those markets over time, thanks to the TPP.
Must Read: Clinton on Trans Pacific Partnership at #DemDebate: 'It Didn't Meet My Standards' 
While Japan doesn't actually impose tariffs on U.S.-made vehicles, American car companies have found it difficult to secure distribution networks in the country and have been subject to separate safety certifications. The TPP sets up a dispute settlement mechanism, including financial penalties, which will ultimately open that market. Granted, while the protections that have prevented American automakers from really penetrating the Japanese market will phase out over the next two decades, it does mean there should be steady sales growth there in the coming years.
The opportunities in the auto industry aren't just limited to American companies, though. North America is already a major market for Toyota Motor Corp.   ( TM - Get Report ) at more than a third of sales and the company has set up a number of production plants here in the U.S. to avoid tariffs.
While Toyota probably won't see a noticeable uptick in its U.S. sales thanks to the agreement, it will see its profit margins expand. That's because it will be able to source more of the parts used in its U.S.-made vehicles from lower cost countries, while still complying with requirements that a certain percentage of parts used come from the U.S., Canada or Mexico. In time, that could boost profit margins on vehicles sold in the U.S. by 5% or more.
